conclusion: Points A and B have equal magnitude like charges. The electric field at the center O is E. The electric potential at O is not given, but the potential at infinity is 0.

premise: Points A and B have like charges.
conclusion: The electric fields they produce at O will be equal in magnitude and direction.

premise: The electric fields from A and B are equal in magnitude and direction.
conclusion: The net electric field at O due to charges at A and B is E.
A charge of equal magnitude but opposite sign is placed at C.

premise: A charge of equal magnitude but opposite sign is placed at C.
conclusion: This charge will produce an electric field at O that is equal in magnitude to the fields from A and B but in the opposite direction.

premise: The electric field due to the charge at C is equal in magnitude and opposite in direction to the net electric field due to charges at A and B.
conclusion: The net electric field at O will be zero.
The potential at O is the sum of the potentials due to each charge.

premise: The potential at O is the sum of the potentials due to each charge.
conclusion: Initially, the potential at O due to charges at A and B is symmetric.

premise: Adding the opposite charge at C will change the potential at O.
conclusion: Let the potential due to each charge be V.

premise: Initially, the potential at O is 2V (due to A and B).
conclusion: Adding the opposite charge at C will add -V to the potential.

premise: The potential at O is 2V and adding -V from C.
conclusion: The new potential at O is V.

premise: The magnitude of the electric field strength at point O after placing the charge at C is 0. The electric potential at point O is V.
conclusion: The magnitude of the electric field strength at point O is 0. The electric potential at point O is V.
